The promoting role of carbon monoxide in mild conversion of methane to acetic acid on atomically dispersed Ir catalyst anchored in ZSM-5 Bo Liu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Chunyan Xiang Investigation Junye Yang Investigation Ping Sun Investigation Yaxin Yang Investigation Yuanjie Xu Investigation Kunlong Liu Investigation Lizhi Wu Investigation Li Tan Investigation Yu Tang Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ Institute of Molecular Engineering Plus, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, China Institute of Molecular Engineering Plus College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350108 China Institute of Molecular Engineering Plus, College of Chemistry, Fuzhou University, Fuzhou 350108, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The catalytic conversion of methane into value-added products under mild reaction conditions presents a key challenge in heterogeneous catalysis. In this study, we investigate the conversion of methane to acetic acid (CH3COOH) and other methyl oxygenates by using molecule CO as the promoter on Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst. An optimum space–time yield of 7.4 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 to acetic acid was achieved under mild conditions (2.5 MPa CH4, 2.5 MPa CO, 80 °C). The influence of CO on methane conversion was investigated across various transition metals. Ir, Fe, Rh, and Pd showed promotion towards oxygenated compound formation, while Cu and Cr exhibited inhibition. Sequential charging of CH4 and CO experiments reveal the critical role of CO in acetic acid production. Furthermore, the role of CO was further investigated by in situ Raman, in-situ FTIR and EPR. This work shows the role of CO in mild conversion of CH4 to CH3COOH on Ir catalyst. Keywords Methane Carbon monoxide Acetic acid Iridium Zeolite C–H bond Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane serves as the primary component of natural gas, shale gas and biogas, offering an economical resource with abundant reserves [1–4]. Its potential as a crucial feedstock for transitioning from fossil fuel-based energy to cleaner, renewable energy sources has gained significant attention [5–8]. However, owing to its substantial C–H bond strength (439 kJ/mol) and the symmetric tetrahedron structure, methane stands out as one of the most inert hydrocarbon molecules, [7–10] rendering methane activation a formidable challenge and known as a “holy grail” reaction in heterogeneous catalysis [11–15]. The direct conversion of methane into liquid products (such as CH3COOH, HCOOH, CH3OH, etc.) using oxidants (H2O2, O2, N2O, etc.) under mild conditions has emerged as a promising alternative strategy in recent years [16–20]. However, overoxidation of these oxygenates to unwanted CO2 under reaction conditions poses a significant challenge (Scheme 1 ) [21–23]. Consequently, there is an increasing demand for the development of innovative catalysts to enhance the yield of methane conversion products [24,25]. Atomically dispersed metal catalysts have displayed remarkable reactivity and selectivity for methane oxidation due to their excellent atom utilization efficiency and distinct metal-support interaction [3]. Notable examples include Fe, [26–30] Au-Pd, [31–35] Rh [36–39] and Ni [40,41] catalysts. Recently, attention has shifted towards the utilization of CO as a promoter, unlocking new reaction pathways in methane conversion and enhancing catalytic activity. For instance, Rh/ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts have been reported to facilitate the formation of acetic acid from CH4, CO, and O2 at 150 °C, achieving high yields of up to 4.96 and 3.09 mmol·gcat −1·h−1, respectively [42,43]. Similarly, dual nuclear iron sites (Fe-BN) loaded inside molecular sieve micropores have demonstrated the ability to convert methane into formic acid, acetic acid, and other products under CO addition, with 89 % total oxygenates selectivity and 66 % CH3COOH selectivity among oxygenated products at 30 °C [44]. Additionally, a direct co-conversion of methane, carbon monoxide, and hydrogen peroxide into acetic acid catalyzed by Fe/ZSM-5 under mild conditions has been reported, achieving an acetic acid space–time yield of ∼ 12.01 mmol·gcat−1·h−1 with an optimal selectivity of 63.2 % at 50 °C [45]. In recently, the atomic isolated Ni1-O6 in ZSM-5 achieved a remarkable selectivity up to 82.3 % from methane oxidative carbonylation [40]. In addition, a Pd1-ZSM-5 single atom catalyst (SAC) by CO molecules significantly promoted the DMC reaction, giving the highest turnover frequency of 207 h−1 ever reported at room temperature and ∼ 100 % oxygenates selectivity with H2O2 as oxidant [46]. Furthermore, recent research highlights the potential of Ir-based catalysts in activating C–H bond at low temperatures due to their potent electrophilic action and charge modification capabilities [47,48]. These studies underscore the critical role of carbon monoxide in the direct transformation of methane into specific oxygenates. However, while the addition of CO promotes methane carbonylation reactions, further exploration is needed to understand its impact on total methyl oxygenates and its mechanism within the reaction. In this study, we investigate the mild conversion of CH4 to oxygenates in an aqueous medium using H2O2 in the presence of CO, effectively catalyzed by atomically dispersed Ir sites within ZSM-5. Our investigation extends to examining the role of CO during methane oxidation across various transition metals. We observe a promotion effect of CO on the yield of oxygenated compounds for Ir, Fe, Rh, and Pd catalysts, while inhibition is evident for Cu and Cr catalysts. Moreover, our findings from XAFS and DRIFTS-CO analyses underscore the atomically dispersed nature of Ir catalytic sites. Notably, sequential charging experiments comparing CH4 and CO indicate that the generation of acetic acid is mainly linked to CO, further highlighting its role in promoting the overall yield of oxygenates. Additionally, characterization through in situ FT-IR, in situ Raman, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) techniques suggest that the addition of CO facilitates the formation of intermediate on Ir active species, potentially leading to the generation of more ·OH radicals. This result indicate that the Ir species could capture ·OH to generate Ir-OH, which may be an intermediate for further reaction with CO to produce products. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Physical and chemical characterization of Ir/ZSM-5 catalysts The xIr/ZSM-5 (x = 0.05, 0.10, 0.20, 0.50, 1.0 wt%) catalysts were synthesized using impregnation (described in the Supplementary Material). In addition, the fresh catalyst was named as 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 while the catalyst after the reaction was labeled as 0.2Ir/ZSM-5-used. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts are closely related to the catalytic performance of the catalytic system. In order to understand the correlation between structure and performance, various characterizations of H-ZSM-5 and Ir/ZSM-5 catalysts were carried out. The X-ray diffraction patterns of all the samples, as shown in Fig. 1 , could be assigned to the ZSM-5 standard file (JCPDS 79–1173), confirming that the presence of Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst did not alter the crystalline structure of pure H-ZSM-5 zeolite significantly [48,49]. Notably, the diffraction peaks associate with Ir or iridium oxide were not detected for the Ir/ZSM-5 catalysts across various loadings, indicating either highly dispersed Ir species on ZSM-5 or Ir amounts falling below the lower detection limit of XRD. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks of the 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst remained well after the reaction, indicating that the good stability of the catalyst. The distinctive pore structure and acidity of ZSM-5 exert a confinement effect on small molecules such as CH4 diffusing into micropores, effectively lowering the activation energy required for C–H bond dissociation [2,50]. The adsorption–desorption isotherms of all the samples exhibited hysteresis loops consistent with type IV isotherms in Brunaure's classification for mesoporous structures (Figure S1) [51]. Compared with the ZSM-5 catalyst, the prepared Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst demonstrated a slightly decrease in surface area and total pore volume (Table S1), which may be attributed to the fact that the introduction of Ir species did not change the framework structure of the molecular sieves, which is consistent with the observation that there was basically no significant change in the XRD diffraction peaks. Moreover, the variation in Ir loading did not change the texture properties of Ir/ZSM-5, which also indicates that these Ir species are highly dispersed on ZSM-5. As shown in Figure S2a, the infrared absorption peaks observed in 1000–1300 cm−1 for all samples are attributed to the Si-O-Si bond vibration characteristic of ZSM-5. The strong absorption peaks at 800 cm−1 and 550 cm−1 are attributed to Si-O bond in ZSM-5 [52]. These characteristic peaks indicate that the introduction of Ir species did not change the framework structure of the molecular sieves, which is consistent with the XRD results. In addition, the different loadings did not affect the physical structure of Ir/ZSM-5, further supporting the conclusion that these Ir species are highly dispersed on ZSM-5. UV–visible spectroscopy was employed to determine the aggregation state and species type of Ir (Figure S2b). The isolated Ir cationic species (∼214 and ∼ 289 nm), oligomeric IrxOy clusters (∼353 nm) were observed in the UV–Vis spectrum. However, large-sized IrO2 particles (∼543 nm) were not observed in the UV–Vis spectrum [45]. When the Ir loading increases from 0.05 to 1 wt%, the content of oligomeric IrxOy clusters increases significantly. The adsorption band at approximately ∼ 289 nm of the catalyst exhibited significant enhancement with increasing loading, which could be attributed to the charge transfer between oxygen (zeolite) and metal [53,54]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to study the structural morphology and elemental distributions, focusing on the 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 sample. As shown in the TEM image of Fig. 2 a, the lattice spacing of 0.61 nm corresponds to the (110) crystallographic plane of ZSM-5, indicating that the zeolite structural form is present in the 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst [47,48]. The introduction of Ir did not change the zeolite structure. In addition, under low magnification, no aggregation of Ir was found, indicating that Ir particles were well dispersed in ZSM-5 [48,53]. In addition, the EDS pattern also shows the uniform distribution of Ir, Al, Si and O elements on ZSM-5 (Fig. 2b2-b5), which is in good agreement with the XRD pattern. In order to investigate the acidity of the catalyst, temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) experiments were performed. The results are shown in Fig. 3 a and Table 1 . It could be found that ZSM-5 shows obvious desorption peaks around 223 and 426 °C, which correspond to the fact that NH3 strongly adsorbed on the weak acid sites and strong acid sites of ZSM-5. After loading 0.2 wt%Ir to form 0.2Ir/ZSM-5, the corresponding intensity of 426 °C in 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 increases compared with ZSM-5. Further quantitative analysis of acid sites indicates that 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 (12.8 mmol·g−1) contains the higher acid sites compared with the parent ZSM-5 (7.13 mmol·g−1) (Table 1), which demonstrates that the desorption amount of NH3 at the weak and strong acid sites were enhanced by the introduction of Ir [51,55]. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption studies indicate that the intensity of Brønsted acid sites increased when the Ir species was introduced on the ZSM-5 zeolite (Figure S3 and Table S3) [45,56]. In order to investigate the surface redox properties of the catalysts, the reduction behavior of the as-prepared 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst was analyzed by H2-TPR (Fig. 3b and Table 1). Two reduction peaks are observed at 242 °C and 350 °C. The intensity and width of the two peaks are distinct. The reduction peak at 242 °C is attributed to the reduction of Ir cationic sites. However, the broad width of the peak at 350 °C implies it might be attributed to the removal of surface hydroxyl group, which cannot be distinguished by the TCD detector [57]. In addition, further quantitative analysis of H2 consumption indicates that 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 (0.47 mmol·g−1) has higher H2 consumption compared with the parent ZSM-5 (0.01 mmol·g−1) (Table 1). With Ir loading increased to 1.0 wt%, the reduction peak at ∼ 242 °C and ∼ 350 °C shifted backward to ∼ 244 °C and ∼ 408 °C, respectively (Figure S4). In addition, further quantitative analysis of H2 consumption indicates that 1.0Ir/ZSM-5 (1.38 mmol·g−1) has higher H2 consumption compared with the parent 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 (0.47 mmol·g−1) (Table S4), indicated that more Ir cationic sites may exist at high Ir loading (1.0 wt%), and Ir species are highly dispersed in the ZSM-5 at lower loading (0.2 wt%). To evaluate the impact of Ir loading on methane adsorption, CH4-TPD experiments were performed (Fig. 3c and Table 1). Compared with pure ZSM-5, the desorption intensity of the Ir-containing catalyst was elevated, while the desorption temperature (205 °C) showed no significant difference. This suggests that the introduction of iridium likely enhances methane adsorption by increasing its adsorption capacity (the CH4 desorption amount of 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 (1.37 mmol·g−1) is higher than pure ZSM-5 (0.24 mmol·g−1)) [48,57]. To investigate the adsorption and desorption behavior of the catalyst towards CO, CO-TPD experiments were conducted. A distinct desorption peak corresponding to weak CO desorption was observed in the low temperature region for the ZSM-5 sample (Fig. 3d and Table 1) [57]. In comparison with ZSM-5, the desorption peaks of CO were notably enhanced for 0.2Ir/ZSM-5. The high-temperature desorption peaks indicate strong CO adsorption. The CO desorption amount of 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 (0.92 mmol·g−1) is higher than that of pure ZSM-5 (0.36 mmol·g−1). This suggests that the presence of iridium promotes CO adsorption, resulting in an increase in the quantity of adsorbed CO. Moreover, the desorption temperature of CO on 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 differed from that on bare H-ZSM-5, suggesting that the surface adsorption and desorption properties may be influenced by the presence of Ir species. 2.2 Catalytic performance of Ir/ZSM-5 catalysts for methane conversion under mild conditions The impacts of various metal loadings, reaction pressures, reaction temperatures, reaction times, H2O2 concentrations and reuse of the catalyst were explored. Each data point was obtained from at least two independent experiments conducted under the same conditions. Detailed procedures for catalyst performance testing and post-reaction product analysis are outlined in the experimental section of the Supporting Information. The corresponding calibration curves for CO2, methanol, formic acid, and acetic acid are shown in Figures S6 and S7. Typical 1H NMR spectra of the products obtained from the methane, carbon monoxide, and hydrogen peroxide reaction catalyzed by 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 are shown in Figure S8. The effect of reaction pressure on the catalytic performance is shown in Fig. 4 a-4c. When methane alone was used as the reaction gas, the majority of the generated products comprised formic acid. With the increase of CH4 pressure from 1.0 MPa to 5 MPa, the amount of the oxygenate products showed an increasing trend, with no production of acetic acid observed when the reaction pressure was rise from 1.0 to 5.0 MPa (Fig. 4a). The introduction of a specific pressure of CO into the reaction gas led to the appearance of acetic acid among the oxygenates products. The product amount of acetic acid remained relatively stable, but the selectivity of acetic acid increased slightly and then leveled off due to the decrease in the other products (HCOOH, CH3OH and CH3OOH) when the CH4 pressure was maintained at 0.5 MPa and the CO pressure was increased from 0.5 MPa to 4.5 MPa. In addition, further increases of the CO partial pressure reduced the selectivity of the oxygenates, resulting in decreased yields of formic acid, methanol, and methyl hydroperoxide, which may be likely due to the insufficient partial pressure of CH4 and poisoning of the catalyst with the increase of the partial pressure of CO (Fig. 4b). On the contrary, when the CO pressure was set to 0.5 MPa while the CH4 pressure was tuned from 0.5 MPa to 4.5 MPa, the yields of acetic acid and total oxygenates exhibited an upward trend (Fig. 4c). It is worth noting that the selectivity of acetic acid kept slowly increasing. The sharp increase in CO2 production with increasing CO partial pressure and the consistent trend in the CO2 production with increasing CH4 partial pressure suggested that CO2 was mainly originated from the CO oxidation (Figure S9). It is noteworthy that the selectivity of the oxygenates followed a distinct trend with the increasing total pressure, with higher methane partial pressure favoring oxygenate formation, while increased CO partial pressure led to decreased yields of formic acid, methanol, and methyl hydroperoxide. Titration experiment (Table S1) revealed that at least 31.2 % of H2O2 was consumed under 2.5 MPa CH4, 2.5 MPa CO, 80 °C, and 1 h. The influence of ratio of CH4/CO on the mild conversion of methane was investigated at seven distinct CH4/CO ratios: CH4 (5 MPa), 9/1, 7/3, 1/1, 3/7, 1/4 and CO (5 MPa) (Fig. 5 a). A volcano shape plot of acetic acid yield can be observed. The maximum acetic acid amount was obtained at PCH4/PCO=1/1, while the selectivity of acetic acid was about 52.1 %. Notably, the increase in CO partial pressure from the CH4/CO ratio of 9/1–1/1 enhanced the yield and selectivity of acetic acid. However, a further increase in CO partial pressure decreased the acetic acid yield (the CH4/CO ratio of 1/1–1/9). The decreased yield of acetic acid and other oxygenates may be due to the reduced CH4 partial pressure. Therefore, the optimum performance of the catalysts was found at a ratio of CH4/CO=1. The sharp increase in CO2 yield with the augment of CO partial pressure indicates that CO2 is mainly originated from the oxidation of CO (Figure S10a). The effect of reaction temperature on the product formation was studied at six different temperatures: 30, 50, 70, 80, 90 and 100 °C. The results are shown in Fig. 5b. The production of oxygenates and the selectivity of acetic acid increased when rising reaction temperature from 30 °C to 80 °C. It is noteworthy that acetic acid formation commenced as low as 30 °C, reaching maximum selectivity of 52 % at 80 °C. Subsequently, as the reaction temperature increased from 80 °C to 100 °C, the content of acetic acid began to decrease, with selectivity decreasing to approximately 35 %. In addition, the yield of formic acid exhibited an upward trend with increasing temperature from 30 °C to 100 °C. However, at 100 °C, a decrease in oxygenate selectivity to 82.4 % was observed, accompanied by reduced content of formic and acetic acid. Therefore, optimal catalyst performance was attained at 80 °C, suggesting favorable catalytic activity at elevated temperatures. The effect of reaction time on product characterization was studied as shown in Fig. 5c. Acetic acid selectivity exhibited an initial increase from 0.5 h to 1 h, followed by a decrease from 2 h to 9 h. The reaction time was observed to correlate positively with acetic acid selectivity. In contrast, the yield of formic acid exhibited a distinct trend compared to acetic acid, increasing with prolonged reaction duration. This observation suggests that overoxidation and C–C coupling reactions collectively dictate the course of methane oxidation at extended reaction times. Meanwhile, the yields of methanol and methyl hydroperoxide remained relatively stable over the 9-hour period, likely due to the stabilizing influence of overoxidation reaction facilitated by C–C coupling. Thus, the optimal reaction time for acetic acid generation was determined to be 1 h. The effect of Ir content on Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst was studied using varying Ir loading of 0.05, 0.10, 0.20, 0.50 and 1.0 wt% (Fig. 5d). The selectivity of acetic acid exhibited a volcano-shaped curve as the function of Ir content, peaking at 0.20 wt%. Conversely, formic acid and CO2 yields demonstrated an increasing trend with higher metal loading (Figure S10d). Furthermore, the production amount of methanol and methyl peroxide remained relatively stable with increasing Ir content. However, the yield of formic acid and CO2 generally increased with Ir loading increased, thus the acetic acid selectivity of the volcanic trend was observed (Fig. 4d). The impact of varying H2O2 usage on product yield was investigated across five different concentrations: 0, 0.25, 0.50, 0.75 and 1 mL (Fig. 5e). As the H2O2 dosage increased from 0.25 to 0.5 mL, the yields of acetic acid, formic acid, methanol, and methyl hydroperoxide showed an increase trend. An optimal selectivity of acetic acid was 52.2 %. However, with a further increase in H2O2 dosage from 0.5 to 1 mL, the acetic acid selectivity decreased from 52.2 % to 40.1 %. This decrease could be attributed to the competitive oxidation reactions occurring at excessive H2O2 concentrations. The yields of CH3COOH, HCOOH, and CH3OH remained virtually unchanged over the course of five consecutive cycles of methane selective oxidation (Fig. 5f), highlighting the stability of Ir/ZSM-5 as a catalyst. Similarly, the selectivity of acetic acid exhibited a slight decrease but remained stable at around 50 % over the five consecutive cycles. This decrease is associated with the catalyst reaction time. XRD and EXAFS analyses conducted on the reacted Ir/ZSM-5 (Figs. 1 and 7) revealed no significant alteration in the used catalyst compared to the fresh catalyst, suggesting the relative stability of Ir/ZSM-5. The variation in the space–time yield (STY) of acetic acid elucidates the primary factors influencing catalyst activity. As depicted in Table S2, a comparable CH3COOH yield of 7.4 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 was achieved when the 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 reaction at the best condition (CH4/CO ratio was 1/1, reaction temperature was 80 °C, reaction time was 1 h, used amount H2O2 was about 0.5 mL). In addition, the ratio of CH4/CO exhibited a remarkable impact on the STY of acetic acid. This finding indicated that a suitable CO partial pressure is advantageous for the CH3COOH selectivity and CH3COOH products keep stable in liquid products. To gain deeper insights into the changes in product properties of Ir/ZSM-5 in the CH4 + CO reaction system, we explored the reactive of Ir on various supports and investigated the catalytic conversion of methane facilitated by different metal/ZSM-5 catalysts (Fig. 6 ). Previous studies have demonstrated that H-ZSM-5 loaded Rh, Pd, and Fe catalysts exhibit promising catalytic performance in the direct conversion of methane to CH3COOH. Fig. 6a illustrates the preparation and evaluation of other metal loaded ZSM-5 catalysts (Rh [43], Pd [31], Cr [58], Cu [30], and Fe [48] prepared by literatures) for methane conversion. Notably, all metal species were atomically dispersed within the ZSM-5 support. Ir/ZSM-5, Rh/ZSM-5, Pd/ZSM-5, and Fe/ZSM-5 displayed similar catalytic properties, characterized by high acetic acid selectivity. However, the Cu/ZSM-5 and Cr/ZSM-5 catalysts exhibited distinct behavior compared to other metals. Cu/ZSM-5 demonstrated a lower oxygenate yield and acetic acid selectivity but exhibited a methanol selectivity of over 60 %. Conversely, Cr/ZSM-5 displayed minimal acetic acid content with CO addition, despite producing other oxygenate products. We also investigated the impact of different supports on catalytic performance (Fig. 6b). Oxide (TiO2, ZrO2, Nb2O3) loaded Ir catalysts exhibited low oxygenate yields (<50 μmol), while S-1 and MOR zeolites loaded catalysts demonstrated a mediocre acetic acid selectivity of about 30–40 %, albeit with low contents. Compared to other active metals and supports, Ir/ZSM-5 demonstrated superior methane conversion efficiency (Figure S11). 2.3 Identification of the atomically dispersed Ir1O4 catalytic site To further understand the nature of the reactive Ir species, diffusive reflectance infrared Fourier transformed spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were performed on 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 at 25 °C using CO as a probe molecule (DRIFTS-CO, Figure S5). The DRIFTS-CO spectra were collected for the ZSM-5, fresh 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 and 0.2Ir/ZSM-5-used samples. The adsorption of CO on Ir sites is relative weak under room temperature [57,59]. In order to avoid the peak phase of metal sites adsorbing CO, the spectrum is collected under the steady flow of CO). Two peaks at 2170 and 2115 cm−1 could be observed for the characteristic bands of gaseous CO molecule. Notably, the 0.2Ir/ZSM-5-used (catalyst after reaction) exhibited a distinct peak at 2056 cm−1, which was attributed to the CO adsorbed on Ir sites in a linear geometry, confirming that Ir sites are highly dispersed in ZSM-5 [57,60]. Thus, the DRIFTS-CO data clearly indicate the presence of singly dispersed Ir species. The electron state and coordination environment of the Ir catalytic sites on the fresh and used 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 catalysts were investigated using X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra (Fig. 7, Table 2 ). In the XANES of Ir L3 edge spectra (Fig. 7a), the heights of the white line of the fresh and used 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 catalysts fall between that of Ir foil and IrO2 references [48,57]. Specifically, the heights of the white line are between Ir foil and IrO2, suggesting that the Ir species in 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 are cationic sites (Figure S14 and Table S5). In addition, the valence state of Ir is estimated based on the intensity of the white line of Ir L3 edge, and the results are shown in the Figure S14 and Table S5. The correlation between valence state and the white-line intensity could be found by the data from Ir foil and IrO2 references. The valence state of the Ir in the Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst could be estimated to be + 1.26 and + 1.65 for the fresh and used catalyst. The Fourier transformed EXAFS of the Ir L3 edge were further fitted with the Ir-O coordination pathway (Fig. 7b-d and Table 2). The coordination number of Ir-O (approximately 1.97 Å) for the fresh and used 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 catalysts is 4.3 ± 0.4 and 4.7 ± 0.4, respectively [48,57]. Wavelet transform (WT) analysis also validates the absence of Ir-Ir coordination structure, suggesting the uniform dispersion of Ir single atoms (Figure S15). 2.4 The role of CO for the mild conversion of methane The control experiments demonstrated a significant enhancement in the catalytic performance of Ir/ZSM-5 following the incorporation of CO reaction pressure. To assess its uniqueness, comparison experiments involving CO, CH4, and CH4 + CO were conducted for a various of transition metal loaded in ZSM-5 (Fig. 8 ). The results revealed that Fe/ZSM-5, Ir/ZSM-5, Rh/ZSM-5, and Pd/ZSM-5 exhibited similar catalytic performance, with a 2–4 folds’ increase in oxygenates content and a significant increase in oxygenates selectivity and acetic acid content upon CO partial pressure. However, Cu/ZSM-5 and Cr/ZSM-5 exhibited notable differences compared to other metal catalysts. The oxygenates content and selectivity of Cu/ZSM-5 catalysts decreased after the addition of CO partial pressure, while their methanol content increased. Similarly, the performance of the Cr/ZSM-5 catalyst is consistent with that reported in literature [58]. However, the oxygenates content and selectivity of Cr/ZSM-5 catalysts decreased both before and after the addition of CO partial pressure. This discrepancy could be attributed to the strong interaction between Cr and CO, resulting in CO poisoning the reaction. The addition of CO has been demonstrated to improve the selectivity of oxygenated products, particularly for formic and acetic acids (Fig. 9 ). Therefore, the role of CO was investigated by comparing the sequence of CH4 and CO introduced into the reactor. As shown in Fig. 9, when performing A sequence (3.0 MPa CH4, reaction for 2 h), only some oxygenates were produced without formation of acetic acid. When performing B and C sequences (2.0 MPa CH4 reaction for 1 h, then add 1.0 MPa CO reaction for another 1 h; 1.0 MPa CO reaction for 1 h, then add 2.0 MPa CH4 reaction for another 1 h), it was found oxygenates were produced, including acetic acid. When performing D sequence (2.0 MPa CH4 and 1.0 MPa CO, reaction for 2 h), the yield of oxygenates was significantly increased. It shows that the addition of CO promotes the generation of acetic acid and also facilitates the generation of formic acid. These results suggested that the CH4 → CH3OH/CH3COOH→HCOOH process may be a parallel reaction. In order to further understand the role of CO in methane activation, in-situ DRIFTS studies were conducted. As shown in Fig. 10 c, under the reactive atmosphere of CH4 + CO (co-feed), infrared bands of gas-phase CO appeared at 2162 cm−1 and 2115 cm−1 during the pre-reaction period (3–60 min in Fig. 10c), while the infrared features for CO adsorbed on It sites were not observed [48,60]. As the reaction proceeded (to 50 min), the peak of CO adsorbed on Ir emerged at 2056 cm−1, indicating the formation of Ir-CO coordination during the reaction. This observation is consistent with the results of the DRIFTS-CO experiments, confirming both the occurrence of the reaction and the presence of Ir species on the surface of ZSM-5 (Figure S5). Furthermore, the peaks attributed to *CH3 groups (2800 ∼ 3000 cm−1 and 1305 cm−1) [61,62] and HCOO– (1370 cm−1) [39,61] became more prominent under CH4 + CO conditions, whereas these peaks were relatively weak in the absence of introduced CO (Fig. 10b and d). In addition, the peak located at 1630 cm−1, which is assigned to the *C=O bond, [39,63] which suggests the formation of C=O bond is a rate determining step in CO assisted methane oxidation [43,64]. The peak intensities of acetic acid (1460 cm−1) [37,39] under CH4 + CO conditions were much stronger than those of the *CH3O species (2800 ∼ 3000 cm−1 and 1036 cm−1) [65] under pure CH4 conditions, indicating the promotion of the Ir-CO ligand environment for the ·CH3 coupling reaction (Fig. 10b and d). These DRIFTS results further confirm the crucial role of Ir-CO coordination in promoting CH4 activation and conversion. To reveal the changes on Ir species on the 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 during the reaction, ex-situ and in-situ Raman spectroscopy was conducted (Fig. 11 ). The ex-situ Raman spectra of 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 before and after the reaction are summarized in Figure S12. The results showed that the 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst exhibits the typical Raman bands of Ir-O corresponding to the symmetry modes of A1g (750–760 cm−1) and Eg (550–570 cm−1) before and after the reaction [66]. The bands at 800–950 cm−1 are attributed to the ZSM-5 zeolite with −Si-OH groups or Si-O-Si groups, and no changes were found before or after the reaction. For the in-situ Raman spectroscopy, Ar was firstly purged at 80 °C for 10 min, then the gas was switched to CH4/Ar and purged for 10 min, then CO was introduced and purged for 10 min. No obvious structural changes were found for 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 when CH4 introduced. However, it is noteworthy that the intensity of Ir-O peaks at 400–500, and 600–700 cm−1 [66] and Ir-OH peak at 700–900 cm−1 [67] increased when CO was added, suggesting that the addition of CO can promote the formation of Ir active intermediates. Recently, Wu et al investigated a Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst by in situ Raman to determine the route of acetic acid formation [45]. They reported that −Fe-OCH3 and −Fe-OOH might be the intermediates, which is in-line with our results. The radicals were captured by 5,5 dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) and then analyzed by electron paramagnetic resonance. As shown in Fig. 12 , ·OH was exhibited weak signals in ZSM-5 and 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 before CO addition. Once CO was added, the signal of ·OH increases significantly, which confirms that the selective oxidation of methane on 0.2Ir/ZSM-5 in H2O2 solution is initiated by free radicals and ·OH intensity increases with the addition of CO, which may be due to the formation of intermediate Ir active species [30,68]. This results indicate that the Ir species may extract H atoms from methane or capture ·OH to generate Ir-OH, which may be an intermediate for further reaction with CO to produce products. In order to eliminate the possibility of CH3COOH formation through the conversion of CH3OH or HCOOH with CO, control experiments were performed utilizing CH3OH+CO+H2O2, CH3COOH+CO+H2O2, and HCOOH+CO+H2O2 when CH4 was excluded from the reactants. From Figure S13 and Table S6, it was observed that intermediate products such as CH3OH and CH3COOH can react further in the presence of CO to generate HCOOH, indicating that the addition of CO promotes the production of oxygenates. Furthermore, it was determined that HCOOH and CH3OH react in the presence of CO to produce HCOOH and CO2, but not CH3COOH. This finding implies that the formation of CH3COOH results directly from the coupling of CH4 and CO, rather than through the involvement of intermediate products. Based on the above experiments and results, we propose a role for CO in the reaction pathway. Scheme 2 illustrates the process of selective methane oxidation by H2O2 and CO over the Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst. Upon activation at the Ir site, H2O2 dissociates into ·OOH and ·OH radicals, which oxidize CH4 to ·CH3 radicals with the assistance of ·OH. The ·CH3 radicals then react with ·OOH and ·OH radicals to yield CH3OOH and CH3OH, while CO reacts with ·CH3 and ·OH to generate acetic acid. Additionally, CO reacts with CH3OH and CH3COOH to promote the production of HCOOH, which represents the primary reaction in methane oxidation. Secondary reactions include overoxidation to unwanted CO2. Presence of atomically dispersed Ir sites in ZSM-5 enhances the activation of C–H bond, and the addition of CO augments the trapping capacity of ·OH radicals. Through the synergy between CO and Ir1O4 species, the Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst demonstrates remarkable catalytic performance in the selective oxidation of methane. 3 Conclusions In this work, a series of ZSM-5-supported metal catalysts were prepared by impregnation and used for the CO-assisted conversion of methane to CH3COOH and other methyl oxygenates. The ZSM-5-supported Ir species can afford an optimal acetic acid space–time yield of 7.4 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 was achieved under a reaction condition (2.5 MPa CH4, 2.5 MPa CO, 15 mL H2O, 0.5 mL 30 % H2O2, 80 °C, 1 h.). The results showed that the catalytic methane oxidation was characterized differently for different metal active centers, with the promotion of oxygenated compound yield enhancement for metals such as Ir, Fe, Rh, and Pd, whereas for metal catalytic units such as Cu and Cr, the addition of CO rather inhibited the oxidation of methane. XAFS and DRIFTS-CO experiments demonstrate that the relatively high oxygenates yields are attributed to atomically dispersion of Ir species. The absorption and desorption results (CO-TPD and CH4-TPD) indicate that atomically dispersion of Ir species have strong adsorption and desorption abilities towards the reactants (CO and CH4). The experiment of comparison of CH4 and CO sequentially charged indicated that the generation of acetic acid is only related to CO, and CO can promote the yield of overall oxygenates. In addition, in situ FT-IR, in situ Raman and EPR confirm that the addition of CO promotes the formation of intermediate Ir active species (Ir-O, Ir-OH), which may in turn produce more ·OH radicals. We believe that CO in this work shows its roles at different metal sites, paving the way for the next design of other metal catalysts for efficient methane conversion. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic conversion of methane into value-added products under mild reaction conditions presents a key challenge in heterogeneous catalysis. In this study, we investigate the conversion of methane to acetic acid (CH3COOH) and other methyl oxygenates by using molecule CO as the promoter on Ir/ZSM-5 catalyst. An optimum space–time yield of 7.4 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 to acetic acid was achieved under mild conditions (2.5 MPa CH4, 2.5 MPa CO, 80 °C). The influence of CO on methane conversion was investigated across various transition metals. Ir, Fe, Rh, and Pd showed promotion towards oxygenated compound formation, while Cu and Cr exhibited inhibition. Sequential charging of CH4 and CO experiments reveal the critical role of CO in acetic acid production. Furthermore, the role of CO was further investigated by in situ Raman, in-situ FTIR and EPR. This work shows the role of CO in mild conversion of CH4 to CH3COOH on Ir catalyst.
